title: Can I use “usually” in past tense? - Quora

response.answer_text: “Usually” is an adverb. It denotes how often something is done. In a range of options, it might be considered the opposite of “seldom.” Adverbs have no tense because they are not verbs. “Usually” does not mean the same as “used to.” When someone says he/she usually goes for a walk in the morning, that means the person walks OFTEN, not seldom. In contrast, “used to” is a colloquial way to express a simple past tense instead of using “was” or “did.” When someone says he/she used to walk in the morning, that means the person either no longer chooses the morning for the time of exercise, or he/she no longer walks, but might use that time for something else now. Just because the two words begin with the same first two letters, they are no longer closely related nor have similar meanings. The adverb “usually” is related to the adjective “usual.” “Used” and “used to” might have come from the verb “use” at one time. Look at its Latin root “utor, uti, usus= use.” You will see it comes from a Latin deponent verb, not an ordinary one in the language. The concept of “using something” is complex. The words “used to” have become a substitute for an auxiliary verb in the same category with “ought to, should, may, might, must.” These concepts do not translate well from other languages into the English language, which does not convey subjunctive modal concepts easily. Therefore, instead of saying “He used to walk.” switch to “He walked.” or “He was walking.” Add in an adverb or adverbial prepositional phrase to explain when or how often. “He usually walked in the morning, but now he stops at the athletic club before he goes to work.” That means, “He was walking often in the past, but he no longer walks.” (Note: If you change the position of the adverb “usually,” it changes the meaning! “He walked usually in the morning. . . “ The focus is on the prepositional phrase “in the morning” instead of the verb! It signals that he walked earlier in the day, but now he walks in the evening. So, the placement of the adverb is important.) If he is still walking in the morning: “He usually walks in the morning even on days when it rains or is cold outside.” That means, “He often walks, and he is still doing it.” Again, the placement of the adverb between the subject and predicate shows the action of walking is more important than conditions which might preclude the action! I’d rather use “frequently” or “often”. I place adverbs at the ends of sentences, so I wouldn’t use “usually” because it sounds wonky. “We went there usually.”  “We went there frequently” sounds better to me.  Rob
Positively, as in the examples below : They usually hung around together most of the time. The teacher usually worked on till late at night. They ate, as they usually did, in the kitchen.
Yes, you can, to describe a habitual, repeated action at a point of time in the past. For example: He usually dined alone.The children usually played in the park.
